information.title: project Information
information.description: Read about our brand studio project were we created our own brand that stands out of others and shows who we are.
information.fullDescription: Our team project is about creating a studio brand for our company, UXY (UXYnergy). We worked hard to develop a brand identity that truly represents who we are. We focused on the brand’s voice, logo, and visual style to create something unique and memorable. Our main goal was to build a brand that feels fun, stands out from the crowd, and shows the strong spirit of our team. In this project, we’ll take you through every step of the process. You’ll see everything from the initial sketches and wireframes to the stylescapes, version control, and detailed planning that went into the project.

1.title: sketches
1.description:
Why: I wanted to make sure our brand identity was clear so that our logo and visuals truly represent who we are and connect with our audience.

What: I started by organizing team discussions to decide on our brand’s voice and personality. We voted on our brand’s key characteristics, like our values and mission. I put everything we agreed on into a brand document, so we could keep our ideas organized and make sure our design choices fit our brand’s message.

How: This document now guides our design for the logo, colors, and shapes, so each part matches our brand identity. Through this, I learned how to bring together everyone’s ideas into one clear plan. I also learned how to think about design from the audience’s point of view, making sure each visual choice communicates our brand clearly.

1.title: stylescape
1.description:
Why: I wanted to make a stylescape to get a strong visual feel for the brand. This would help keep our designs true to our brand’s personality and make sure they appeal to our audience.

What: I looked for images and design elements that showed our brand’s main values (fun, eye-catching, and dynamic). Finding the right visuals was hard, and it took time to pick images that really matched our brand. I focused on pictures that fit our brand’s core look and would help us keep a consistent design style.

How: In the end, the stylescape helped bring our brand vision to life. It made it easier to design visuals that match our brand identity. This process taught me how to turn brand ideas into real visuals, which will help in future design work. It also helped me improve my skills in creating a consistent look and feel for the brand, which is important in media design.

2.title: github
2.description:
Why: I wanted to improve team communication and workflow, so everyone could easily access and update our project files.

What: set up a GitHub repository with a simple structure that everyone could follow. This made it easy to organize and share our work in one place. The setup process was simple and didn’t take much time.

How: In the end, the GitHub repository helped our team work together more smoothly. It kept our files organized and made it easy to track changes. This experience taught me that it can be really handy, since i had a merge conflict and I needed to go back to the old version.

3.title: business cards
3.description:
Why: I wanted to create business cards that clearly show our brand’s identity using our brand’s color palette.

What: I designed three business cards, making sure to use our brand’s colors. After getting feedback from our teacher, I changed the logo to show unity and teamwork by making the puzzle pieces fit together. The teacher also suggested using bright colors, so I added them to make the design fun and eye-catching. I also looked for design ideas on Awwwards and Pinterest.

How: Designing these business cards helped me think creatively and mix both feedback and my own ideas. I had to find a way to make the logo represent unity and teamwork through the puzzle design. The bright colors made it hard to keep the design professional but still fun. The feedback helped me improve my work, and I learned how to apply feedback to improve my designs and make them more polished and professional, which is important for working in a real-world project.

3.title: wireframes
3.description:
Why: I wanted to create clear wireframes for the website to plan how it would look and work, making sure it was easy to use and matched our brand.

What: I started by making a simple wireframe in Figma to plan the website layout. When I worked on the more detailed wireframe, I asked for feedback from the team. They said I should add more images, use more colors, and think about how to show the puzzle pieces in the design. I also made the header navigation easier to read and changed the colors to match the new branding.

How: The design process went well, but we had some problems with how to show the puzzle pieces and organize the website. We solved these problems together, and I learned how to improve my designs based on feedback. I also learned how to adjust my work when things change. Next time, I would spend more time improving the design and better manage my time. I then turned the wireframes into a real website, using what I learned.

3.title: website
3.description:
Why: I wanted to turn the wireframe designs into a working website that looked like the design, was easy to use, and worked well on all devices.

What: I followed the wireframes carefully to build the website, making sure it looked like the design. I also made sure the website worked well on mobile devices, adjusting the layout for smaller screens. There were no big problems with talking to my colleague, and time management was not an issue. I also made sure the code was easy to read by organizing the files well, using the right names, and adding comments to explain things.

How: Building the website went well, and I was able to make it work as planned. I learned how important it is to keep the code clean and easy to understand. This helped me improve my coding skills and feel more confident in making websites that work well, look good, and are easy to maintain.

4.title: process
4.description:
Why: At the start of the project, we needed to stay organized and keep everyone updated. I set up trello with our group to track our goals, so we could easily share our progress with the stakeholders.

What: During the project, one of my teammates needed help with using GitHub and branches. I taught him how to use it, so he could work better. I also made sure to update the team on my progress, so they knew where we were in the project.

How: I used Trello to track and share our progress with the team and stakeholders. I helped my teammate with GitHub, making sure he understood how to use it. I also focused on making the website accessible for both mobile and desktop users, so it met the current web standards and trends. This helped the team stay on track and ensured we were working professionally.

5.title: personal leadership
5.description:
Why: At the beginning of the project, we talked about what we are good at and where we need to improve. I knew I could help with development because I have some experience. I also realized that planning is a weakness for me, so I wanted to work on that while helping the team.

What: I decided to help with development since I felt confident. To improve my planning skills, I helped set up Trello and made sure everything was moving along. Giving feedback to the team helped me understand how I can improve my communication and decision-making.

How: I used my skills in development to help the team. I worked on my planning by setting up Trello and keeping everything organized. I also learned that better communication would help the team make decisions faster. Next time, I want to focus on talking directly with the team so we can work more efficiently and make better decisions. This project helped me see my strengths and weaknesses, which will help me grow as a frontend developer.

information.title: project Information
information.description: Read about my portfolio project were I created a website to display my work and my passion.
information.fullDescription: In my portfolio, I show the process I went through for each project and why I made certain choices. I wanted every decision to be clear and have a purpose, helping the viewer understand my skills and style. I kept the layout simple so that each project is easy to explore. I chose colors, fonts, and design elements that match each project’s theme to make them stand out. I also listened to feedback, which helped me see areas for improvement and made my portfolio look more professional and engaging.

1.title: moodboard
1.description:
Why: I made a moodboard because I wanted to explore different design ideas and find out what really speaks to me. I needed a way to see a variety of styles and ideas all in one place, so I could pick the elements that match my vision. Creating this moodboard helped give me direction and made me think more about what makes a design interesting and effective.

What: For my inspiration, I used the website awwwards.com. This site has some of the best website designs, so it was perfect for finding quality examples. I looked for sites with unique styles, strong visuals, and clear layouts. Then, I collected a mix of design styles, colors, layouts, and interactions to see what stood out to me.

How: Putting these inspirations together in a moodboard helped me clearly see which design principles I like most. It gave me a chance to look at different visual styles and decide what might work for my project. By making this moodboard it helps me with the basics of designing, for example understanding in a design why a element is placed on that particular position with that styling.

1.title: testing flow/design
1.description:
Why: I did flow and design testing document on my portfolio wireframe with 5 people to make sure users could easily find my projects and contact me. I wanted to understand how they felt about the design and structure.

What: I gave them 5 tasks to complete, and based on their feedback, I learned that the menu icon wasn’t clear to users and they wanted a quicker way to navigate to the projects.

How: The testing went well good, since everyone finished their tasks quickly. I got useful feedback that I can improve on, and I’ll definitely do this again in the future because it helped me make the design better.

1.title: interactive prototyping
1.description:
Why: I created an interactive prototype using Figma to see how the final product would look and work. I wanted to test how users would move through the design and make sure it worked well. This helped me see the design more clearly before building it and focused on making a good experience for users.

What: While working on the prototype, I learned how to use Figma’s prototyping tools, like making navigation flows and adding animations. I practiced how users would interact with the design, making it feel more real and dynamic.

How: The prototype helped me see the design in action, and using Figma’s tools showed me how important user flow and interaction are. I now feel more confident in making interactive prototypes. I’ve learned the basics, and this will help me in future projects. Next time, I can explore more advanced features in Figma to make my prototypes even better and more realistic.

1.title: mobile responsiveness
1.description:
Why: I made my portfolio mobile responsive because I want to give my user the option to use any device. I wanted to make sure my portfolio works well on all screen sizes.

What: During the process, I had to make design decisions like changing buttons and text size based on the screen size. This helped me apply user-centered design principles, ensuring that the design is functional and easy to use on both mobile and desktop.

How: Making my portfolio responsive was not too difficult, but it helped me improve my web development skills. It also gave me a chance to explore how to create interactive and engaging media products that work well across different devices. This experience made me better at designing and developing websites with users in mind.

2.title: github
2.description:
Why: I created a GitHub repository to keep track of all my project files and versions. I also added a readme to help others understand what my repository is about. This was helpful because I used GitHub Pages to host my website, which gave me a working URL.

What: The readme explained the purpose of the repository, and using GitHub Pages allowed me to quickly publish and test my website online.

How: By using GitHub and GitHub Pages, I was able to manage my project better and make it accessible online. This process helped me keep everything organized and gave me a simple way to share my website with others.

3.title: wireframes home
3.description:
Why: I created mid-fidelity wireframes to explore the design layout and functionality based on the moodboard I made. This helped me see how the design would look and work before adding more details.

What: I used the moodboard to guide my wireframe design. The wireframes helped me focus on the structure and layout without getting distracted by colors or images.

How: The wireframes helped me plan the layout and test the design’s flow. This step made it easier to improve the design before adding more details later.

3.title: wireframes low
3.description:
Why: I chose the design wireframe I liked and built the full page based on the flow/design testing I did earlier. I wanted to turn my idea into a real layout and see how it would work in practice.

What: I worked through the first stage of the homepage, making changes based on the insights from the testing. This helped me see how the design could be improved.

How: By using the insights to improve the design, I felt more confident about how the homepage was coming together and had clear ideas for future changes.

3.title: wireframes high
3.description:
Why: I turned the wireframes into high-fidelity versions to focus on details and improve the design.

What: I added more details to the wireframes, making them look more like the final design.

How: This process helped me realize how important user feedback is early on, as it helped me make better design choices.

3.title: wireframes updated
3.description:
Why: I chose the design wireframe I liked and built the full page to see how it would work in real life. I wanted to turn my idea into something more practical and see how everything would fit together.

What: I worked on the homepage, making changes based on my teacher's feedback. My teacher suggested making the 'Let's connect' section more eye-catching, using different buttons on the project page, and adding icons for the links.

How: The changes helped improve the design. By testing the design and using feedback, I could see where things needed to be better. These steps made me feel more confident in my choices, and now I have clear ideas for further improvements.

3.title: development
3.description:
Why: I started developing by setting up a GitHub and organizing my workspace with the right folder structure. I followed my Figma design and used ChatGPT to help speed up my coding process. I also added an animation library and FontAwesome for better user experience and easier embedding. I wanted to make sure the project was well-structured and efficient.

What: My teacher gave feedback that my coding structure was good, but suggested I learn more about frameworks, like modules and their structure. I didn’t face many problems, but I asked for feedback on how I could improve my coding skills and avoid bad habits.

How: This feedback made me realize I could improve by looking deeper into frameworks in the future. Although the process wasn’t too hard because of my experience, I’m eager to expand my skills and knowledge to create even better projects.

3.title: the website
3.description:
Why: After getting feedback from my teacher, I realized the project page on the website needed some improvements to make it clearer and easier to use.

What: My teacher suggested making the tabs more obvious so that users know they can click on them. For the learning outcomes section, I was advised to create different sections for each topic to make the page more organized.

How: These changes would help make the page more user-friendly and easier to navigate. By making the tabs clearer and organizing the learning outcomes, the design will be easier to understand and more effective. This feedback will help me keep improving the design in the next steps.

3.title: portfolio structure
3.description:
Why: My teacher gave feedback on the website to make the 'why, what, & how' method easier to see and understand. The 'Learning Outcomes' heading on desktop didn’t fit well, and the links in the learning outcomes needed to be clearer. Also, I should add more text to the project introduction for better context.

What: The feedback was to make the 'why, what, & how' method more visible. On desktop, I should remove the 'Learning Outcomes' heading and add an icon to the links to make them stand out. I also need to show more text in the introduction to give more details.

How: These changes will make the page easier to read and understand. Adding icons and more text will help make the design clearer and more helpful for users. This feedback really helped my design.

4.title: communication
4.description:
Why: During the process of creating my portfolio, I stayed in contact with my teachers and regularly asked for feedback. This feedback was essential in helping me make informed decisions about both my work and the development of my professional skills.

What: By regularly consulting my teachers, I was able to involve a stakeholder (my teacher) who provided advice and feedback on the decisions I was making. This was valuable in shaping my project in a professional manner and improved the overall quality of my work.

How: This process helped me realize the importance of feedback and communication in achieving a professional standard. However, I noticed that while time management and work ethic were effective, I could improve my planning next time by scheduling my tasks more efficiently. This would help me stay organized and streamline my work process, especially when working solo.

5.title: future portfolio
5.description:
Why: For this portfolio, I wanted to create something I could use for my internship or easily adapt for an upcoming internship. My goal was to make it professional and relevant to work and contact, rather than project-based. I aimed to design it in a way that would stand out to potential employers.

What: To achieve this, I focused on aligning the portfolio with current design trends. I made sure the structure was clean and professional, highlighting my skills and contact information to make it easy for potential employers to see my work and get in touch.

How: By creating a portfolio with a professional approach and modern trends, I am more confident it will help me get a good internship. I focused on the details that would make my portfolio stand out and appeal to companies in my field.

5.title: career day/internship
5.description:
Why: I want to go to the career day so I can understand the real work world better. Meeting people who work in the field can give me important knowledge that isn't in books or online. This will help me see which skills I need and give me more confidence in my career path.

What: I’m going to attend the career day to learn more about front-end development. This is something I still need to do, but I believe it will show me what companies want in a developer. I’ll be able to ask questions, hear real stories, and understand more about the work in this field.

How: Attending the career day can help shape my skills and mindset. By talking with people who have real experience, I’ll know what I should focus on learning next. This event is a chance to see where I’m going and figure out the steps I need to take.

information.title: project Information
information.description: Read about my client project I did with my group were we created a fast fashion solution product
information.fullDescription: This project is about finding a solution for fast fashion aimed at teenagers aged 15 to 17. Fast fashion here means the quick and affordable production of trendy clothes, which often has environmental impacts. In this project, we use agile methods like Scrum, working in sprints with retrospectives to review progress. We’re also using the Double Diamond method, which gives us a clear process to follow. Our goal is to understand the issues with fast fashion and create a product that addresses these challenges.

1.title: ripping the brief
1.description:
Why: We started by ripping the brief to fully understand the client’s problem and asked our client some questions based on the problem to identify which areas needed more research. I focused on researching our target audience because understanding their needs and behaviors was crucial for creating a design that would resonate with them.

What: I began with a literature study on our target group. I set up a shared research document in Teams to organize and present my findings clearly. We focused on one main question, and I researched one sub-question with five smaller questions. My research aimed to understand why teenagers buy fast fashion, what motivates them, and why they continue despite the negative environmental and ethical impacts.

How: This research helped us understand that teenagers prioritize price, trends, and convenience when shopping for fast fashion, but are often unaware of the ethical and environmental issues involved. They can be influenced by marketing and education, and the main barriers they face are high costs and limited options for stylish alternatives. This deep understanding of our audience helped guide our design choices and confirmed the importance of focusing on their real needs and behaviors.

1.title: lotus blossom
1.description:
Why: To come up with ideas for our research, we needed a method that would help us think in different ways and explore new ideas. We used the Lotus Blossom method, which started with our main goal: making fast fashion less attractive. This method helped us break the problem down and look at it from different sides.

What: We started by brainstorming ideas around our main goal with the group. I wrote down my thoughts and expanded on them. The Lotus Blossom method helped us come up with several ideas by organizing our thoughts and building on each one. We also used Brain Writing to get more ideas from everyone in the group.

How: This method helped us think of new ways to reach our goal. It was a good way to generate ideas, and I would definitely recommend it for future projects because it helps you focus on important points. After showing our teacher the Lotus Blossom and Brain Writing methods, they advised us to apply co-creation and research methods to each idea with users, do both primary and secondary research for each idea, and have a clear concept before talking to the target audience.

1.title: brainwriting
1.description:
Why: Another method we used to come up with ideas was the Brainwriting method. This method helped us explore many ideas and find possible solutions for our concepts. It encouraged everyone in the group to think creatively and share their ideas.

What: Each member of our group started by writing down their own ideas on our topic. I wrote my ideas down too. After that, we exchanged our ideas and built on each other’s thoughts for several rounds. This allowed us to develop a wider range of ideas.

How: The Brainwriting method helped us think of many different possibilities for our concept. It was really useful for expanding on each other's ideas, and I would recommend using it in the future for idea generation.

1.title: gamification prototype
1.description:
Why: Based on the research I did with my team, I worked on the gamification prototype, focusing on the homepage, level page, and global styling. I wanted to bring the features of tiered rewards and a sharing option into the design. These elements came from our competitor analysis and global research, which gave us insights into what could work well in our app.

What: For the prototype, I created the homepage and level page and applied game mechanics like rewards and sharing options. We based these ideas on our research of successful gamification features.

How: After getting feedback from our teacher, I learned that we needed to better define the 'why' behind the app. We came up with the idea of a reward system to answer this.

1.title: pov & hmw
1.description:
Why: From the problem statement, we created the POV (Point of View): 'As a teenager, I want to buy cheap and trendy clothes so that I fit in.' This helped us focus on the user's needs and develop a clear direction for the project.

What: After establishing the POV, I contributed ideas to brainstorm solutions. We created multiple HMW (How Might We) questions based on these solutions to guide our design process.

How: The POV and HMW process helped me think critically about user needs and develop solutions that directly addressed the problem.

1.title: concept document
1.description:
Why: The concept document was essential for keeping the project on track and aligned with the professional standards required. It helped us present a clear, well-organized overview to the client and our team.

What: For the concept document, I created the entire layout and organized the research findings, including the personas I developed. I also included the ideation process, such as the Lotus Blossom and Brainwriting methods. This helped us keep everything in one place and made it easy to track our progress. The document provided a clear timeline and overview, helping us identify our next steps and ensuring that we stayed focused and organized.

How: The document was very helpful because it acted as a structured reference point for everyone involved. It made it easier to communicate our ideas and progress with the team and the client, keeping everything organized in one accessible place. I really liked this document, as it gave us a clear overview of where we were in the process and what still needed to be done.

3.title: gamification prototype
3.description:
Why: After getting feedback from our teacher, I realized that we needed to refine the concept behind our prototype. We identified the 'why' of the project and used this to develop a clearer vision for the app.

What: Our feedback session led to the idea of adding a reward system to better engage the target audience. This helped us refine our approach and make the prototype more aligned with the needs of our users.

How: I contributed to refining the prototype and ensuring that it reflected the new direction we decided on, making it more clear and user-focused.

4.title: team charter
4.description:
Why: As a group, we created a team charter to set clear roles, expectations, and professional standards for working together. This document helped us establish group norms and standards of quality, which are important for maintaining professionalism in the project.

What: The team charter outlined our roles within the team, success metrics, and consequences if something doesn’t go as planned. It also detailed our group norms and the quality of work we aim to maintain.

How: Creating this document was really useful because it made sure we were all on the same page about how we would collaborate. It helped us set clear guidelines for professionalism and teamwork, and I will definitely use this approach in future projects.

4.title: trello
4.description:
Why: To manage our tasks more effectively, we used Trello. My role was to keep the team leader updated on my progress and check if my work was done correctly.

What: Trello helped us organize our work by setting clear deadlines and receiving alerts. It also supported our agile work environment, where we used scrum and sprints to stay on track.

How: The schedule made it easy to keep everything organized and meet deadlines. However, for future projects, I would consider using a different tool for managing the agile scrum process since Trello doesn't clearly show retrospectives or provide an overview of the entire process.

4.title: literature study
4.description:
Why: Following our teacher’s recommendation, we divided the research tasks into three parts to make the workload more manageable. By doing this, we could focus on specific areas in a methodical way and ensure we were collaborating effectively as a team.

What: I was responsible for researching our target audience. I structured my research by setting up a document in Teams, which allowed for efficient collaboration and easy access for the team. I focused on understanding teenagers’ behaviors and motivations regarding fast fashion. My research showed that teenagers are driven by affordability and trends, but they are largely unaware of the environmental and ethical issues associated with fast fashion.

How: This research process helped us understand how teenagers think and behave in the context of fast fashion. The conclusions provided valuable insights that will guide our design decisions. To validate these findings further, we would conduct surveys and create personas. This professional, team-based approach helped ensure that our project stayed organized and aligned with industry standards. I’d definitely use this method in future projects.

4.title: survey
4.description:
Why: I created survey questions with Justin based on the conclusions of the research document its main question. We focused on topics like affordability, trendiness, convenience, and popular brands like Shein, Zara, and H&M. We also looked at how teens are unaware of the environmental and social impacts of fast fashion, like pollution, unethical labor, and waste. We wanted to see how education and marketing could help change their habits. The survey was designed for our target group, which is 18-24 years old.

What: After creating the survey, we asked our teacher for feedback on the questions. She suggested adding more brands as options and rewording some questions to make them easier to understand. After making these changes, we turned the questions into a survey and added a fun QR code to attract our target group. Our teacher also confirmed that our target group was at the school, so we put the QR code on the walls to make it easier for them to take the survey.

How: After receiving over 19 responses, we analyzed the data. The results showed that our target group (18-24 years old) is not very aware of fast fashion’s impact. Cost was a big factor in their purchasing decisions, and many said they would buy sustainable clothing if it were cheaper. Our survey also showed that both males and females in the 18-24 age range participated, confirming that our target group was accurate. This was very helpful because it gave us valuable insights into our target audience's habits and thoughts. I would definitely use this approach again in future projects.

4.title: persona's
4.description:
Why: Based on the survey, I created two personas that represent our target group. I took the main findings from the survey and added them to these personas. This helped us focus on their needs, frustrations, and other important details.

What: By creating these personas, we were able to simplify and better understand the main characteristics of our target group. It helped us clearly define the people we are designing for.

How: These personas were very useful in finding our target group and understanding them more clearly. I would definitely use this method again for future projects to better focus on the people we want to reach.

4.title: competitor analysis
4.description:
Why: Based on the Lotus Blossom method, we chose 'gamification' as our subject. I researched competitors to understand how they use gamification, and I focused on Starbucks' loyalty program because it has interesting gamification elements.

What: From my competitor analysis, I discovered that Starbucks uses tiered rewards, time-sensitive challenges, and sharing options. These strategies help them keep customers engaged and build long-term brand loyalty by turning satisfied customers into brand advocates.

How: These insights were really helpful for coming up with ideas for gamification in our project. The competitor analysis gave me valuable data to improve our project, and I will definitely use this research method in future projects.

4.title: pov & hmw
4.description:
Why: The POV and HMW method was important for guiding our project in the right direction and ensuring that we were solving real problems.

What: By using POV and HMW, we were able to understand the user’s perspective and develop solutions that made sense. This allowed us to define the problem clearly and start brainstorming effective solutions.

How: The process helped me collaborate better with the team to come up with solutions and showed me the importance of defining problems before jumping into solutions. I believe this approach is essential for every project to stay focused on finding the best possible solution.

4.title: review prototype
4.description:
Why: We showed our prototype to the client, and after getting feedback, I understood the importance of aligning our ideas with client expectations and real-world application.

What: I presented the prototype with the mockups I created. After receiving feedback that the idea wasn't innovative enough, I reflected on how I could improve the approach.

How: The feedback process taught me to focus more on the underlying idea rather than just the design. I realized the importance of delivering a prototype that is both functional and innovative, with clear reasoning behind the concept..

4.title: approval idea
4.description:
Why: The feedback from both our teacher and client was essential to guide the project in the right direction and finalize the idea.

What: After reviewing the feedback, we understood the importance of applying professional standards to make the project engaging, relevant, and aligned with the client’s expectations.

How: The process of refining the idea and presenting it to the client helped improve the quality of the project. I helped combine the information into a clear and concise presentation that was easy to follow. Moving forward, I would keep the presentations shorter and more concise to better communicate our ideas.

5.title: team charter
5.description:
Why: We created a team charter to help us understand each other's strengths and weaknesses. I added my own strengths and weaknesses, as well as my core values. I also wrote down my personal goals and commitments, like improving communication within the team and enhancing our use of version control.

What: In the team charter, we listed our group norms, roles, success metrics, standards of quality, and consequences. This helped clarify our personal goals and how we would work together as a team.

How: I really liked this document because it helped me reflect on my personal growth and goals for the project. It also gave clear guidelines for the team, and I would definitely recommend creating a team charter at the start of every project to guide personal development.

5.title: scrum
5.description:
Why: We used an agile working method, like Scrum, and worked in sprints. Every two weeks, we did a retrospective to talk about how things were going. In the first retrospective, we realized we needed to communicate better, help each other, and make decisions faster. We also had an issue with some team members being late, so we added a strike method for accountability.

What: I participated by adding information to the board during sprints and retrospectives. In the second retrospective, we saw improvements, and everything went really well because we solved our issues with communication and decision-making.

How: This process worked well because the communication got better, and we were able to identify problems quickly through retrospectives. I’ll definitely keep using this approach in the future.

5.title: presenting
5.description:
Why: In sprint/retrospective meetings, I presented what I had done in stand-up sessions. This helped me improve my presenting skills for the team.

What: At first, I wasn’t very confident, but over time, I became better at presenting and speaking in front of others.

How: This experience helped me grow and improve, and I hope it will help me with presenting in a company in the future.

information.title: project Information
information.description: Read about all my challenges I have done to challenge myself and upgrade my knowledge about web development and other interesst
information.fullDescription: On this page, you can see all the challenges I've taken on to push myself and grow my skills. I've worked on various projects to improve my knowledge in web development and other exciting areas like UX/UI design. Each challenge has helped me learn something new, allowing me to try out different ideas, tools, and techniques. By taking on these challenges, I've aimed to build my confidence, expand my abilities, and become better at creating interactive and user-friendly websites. I'm passionate about learning and enjoy testing myself in these different areas, always looking to improve and bring fresh ideas to my work.

1.title: blender character
1.description:
Why: I wanted to build my skills in 3D character creation, focusing on sculpting and rendering techniques to create a character that fits a “party animal” style. By challenging myself to bring this concept to life, I developed foundational sculpting skills, along with UV mapping and texturing methods.

What: For this project, I designed a raccoon character, starting with sculpting tools to create the initial form. I also explored techniques to optimize geometry, which helped me make the model efficient for rendering. After creating the base shape, I moved on to UV mapping, painting, and adding details like fur with a particle system in Blender.

How: This process introduced me to core sculpting tools (like add, remove, and grab) and UV mapping basics, expanding my skill set. I set up lighting to make the scene look polished, learning how these techniques contribute to a professional look.

1.title: api retrieve
1.description:
Why: The task of retrieving data from an API was important because it allowed me to understand how to connect to external sources and integrate their data into a digital product. This is a crucial skill for front-end development and for planning how to make a product dynamic and interactive.

What: I set myself a small challenge to retrieve data from an API in JSON format and display it in cards on a webpage. I used a simple API and successfully integrated the data without any issues. This process was straightforward, and I didn't encounter any major problems during the task. It helped me become more comfortable with fetching and displaying data in web development.

How: This task was helpful because it gave me practical experience working with APIs, which is important for front-end development. It allowed me to see how data is retrieved and displayed dynamically, a key part of building interactive websites. In the future, I plan to work with more complex APIs and integrate multiple databases into one project. This experience has also motivated me to improve my skills in handling larger, more complex data sets.

1.title: api usability
1.description:
Why: The task was important because it allowed me to learn how to use data from an API in a practical and interactive way. By creating a game where users can select their Pokémon and battle, I could understand how to retrieve, process, and display API data, which is a key skill for front-end development.

What: I retrieved data from an API and used it to build a duel-like game where users can select their Pokémon, view information about them, and fight against an opponent. This helped me understand how to work with JSON data in a more practical context and turn it into an interactive element on a webpage.

How: This project was helpful because I applied my knowledge of API data in a more interactive setting. I learned how to handle JSON data and integrate it into a game, allowing me to practice data manipulation and make the content dynamic. The experience was useful for improving my skills in API integration and interactive web features. In the future, I want to create even more complex projects with APIs and expand my knowledge of how to make dynamic content on websites.

1.title: basics react
1.description:
Why: I wanted to learn the basics of using a framework, so I chose React. This was important because understanding frameworks is essential for creating modern web applications, and I wanted to build my skills in a framework widely used in front-end development.

What: I learned how to use React with Vite to set up a project. I worked with basic components, such as buttons, carousels, and text elements. I also explored how to use the React Router to navigate between pages. This gave me hands-on experience with setting up a project, organizing components, and managing page navigation.

How: This experience helped build my confidence in working with frameworks. I learned how to structure a project, create reusable components, and navigate between pages, which are essential skills for front-end development. In the future, I would like to explore other frameworks and understand the differences between them to improve my skills and find the best tools for different projects.

1.title: react 3D object
1.description:
Why: I wanted to learn how to implement 3D objects into a webpage and make them interactive. This was important because integrating 3D elements can enhance the user experience on websites, and I wanted to understand how to combine React with 3D objects.

What: I continued developing my React template and learned how to implement a 3D object by using a library that allows interaction with the object, such as changing its rotation and adding additional objects. I used ChatGPT for guidance on how to correctly import and integrate the 3D object. I also faced issues with exporting my Blender file correctly, as it needed a scene.bin file. However, I learned the proper export settings and can now successfully import Blender objects into my project.

How: This experience helped me understand how to work with 3D models in a web environment, and I now know how to use the library to make 3D objects interactive. I also solved the problem of exporting and importing Blender files correctly, which has improved my workflow. In the future, I would like to explore integrating a database with interactive 3D objects to store and manage data dynamically.

2.title: work enviroment
2.description:
Why: To create a better work environment, I focused on making my code clear and reusable for others. This is important because in companies, multiple people often work on the same codebase, so everyone needs to understand each part easily. Commenting my code helps with this.

What: I made sure to comment on my code wherever necessary, explaining parts that might be unclear to others. This way, anyone who reads it will know what each section does and how to use it.

How: One of my colleagues asked me do you comment your code enough? And i asked myself this question and the case for my was that I didnt do it much, but now I see how small actions, like writing clear comments, make a big difference in a collaborative setting and even when your work alone on a project.

3.title: blender character
3.description:
Why: I wanted to learn 3D sculpting and improve my skills in character creation, so I chose to design a raccoon character in a “party animal” style. This gave me a chance to practice using sculpting tools and learn how to apply feedback to improve my work.

What: I started by shaping the character’s head and body, using sculpting tools to create a raccoon form that matched the style. After a first pass, I showed it to my teacher, who advised me to make the nose more rounded and adjust the mouth indentation to fit the character style better. Based on that, I refined the head structure and continued with UV mapping and texturing. I painted the character using Blender and added fur with a particle system, lighting from a free source, and a simple, curved background.

How: Working on this character taught me key sculpting basics like add, remove, and grab tools, and also how to UV-map and paint. The feedback process was helpful for learning how to adjust my designs based on input, and I want to keep improving on sculpting techniques, painting, and eventually, adding animations.

5.title: exploring 3D
5.description:
Why: I wanted to improve my skills in 3D modeling because it is something often used in web design, which is related to my goal of becoming a front-end developer. This opportunity allowed me to explore 3D design and apply it to my workflow.

What: I took this opportunity to learn and improve my skills in sculpting 3D objects in Blender, specifically for web design applications. By creating a party animal-style character, I gained hands-on experience with sculpting tools, UV mapping, and creating realistic textures. I also explored how 3D models can be used in web design, understanding their role in creating interactive or visual elements for websites.

How: By practicing and refining my 3D modeling skills, I developed a deeper understanding of how 3D objects can enhance web design. This experience was valuable for my development as a front-end developer, as it allowed me to expand my technical skills in areas that are increasingly used in modern web development.

5.title: exploring frameworks
5.description:
Why: I wanted to learn about modern web development trends, especially frameworks like React, because they are used a lot in the industry. Frameworks are important for creating big and easy-to-maintain websites. My teacher suggested I start learning frameworks as feedback, so I decided to focus on React to understand how it works and how it fits in web development today.

What: I used Vite to set up a React project and worked on basic components like buttons, carousels, and text. I also learned to use React Router to navigate between pages. My teacher’s feedback helped me focus on learning the basics of React first, which is important before moving on to more advanced features.

How: This project helped me see how React can be used to build interactive websites. My teacher’s feedback made me realize that learning the basics is essential for improving my skills. Now I feel more confident using React and frameworks in my projects. In the future, I want to learn more about React and other frameworks to build more complex websites.
